prior_works.title: Counterfactual explanations without opening the black box: Automated decisions and the GDPR
prior_works.authors: Sandra Wachter, Brent Mittelstadt, Chris Russell
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ElliCE builds on the standard counterfactual explanation formulation introduced by Wachter et al., but extends it to ensure validity not for a single fitted model, but uniformly over a set of near-optimal models.

prior_works.title: Actionable Recourse in Linear Classification
prior_works.authors: Berk Ustun, Alexander Spangher, Yang Liu
prior_works.role: Optimization-based recourse with costs and constraints
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ElliCE generalizes Ustun et al.’s convex optimization framework for actionable recourse by replacing single-model constraints with robust counterparts that must hold across an entire ellipsoidal model-uncertainty set.

prior_works.title: Predictive multiplicity in classification
prior_works.authors: Charles Marx, Flavio Calmon, Berk Ustun
prior_works.role: Model multiplicity as a practical problem
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By documenting the prevalence and consequences of multiple equally accurate models, this work motivates ElliCE’s central goal of making counterfactual recourse robust to model multiplicity.

prior_works.title: All models are wrong, but many are useful: Learning a variable's importance by studying an empirical Rashomon set of good models
prior_works.authors: Anna Fisher, Cynthia Rudin, Francesca Dominici
prior_works.role: Rashomon set concept and empirical study
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ElliCE operationalizes the empirical Rashomon set idea by proposing an ellipsoidal approximation to this set and optimizing counterfactuals that are guaranteed to be valid throughout it.

prior_works.title: Towards Robust and Reliable Algorithmic Recourse
prior_works.authors: Suvrat Upadhyay, Shiv Shankar Joshi, Himabindu Lakkaraju
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ElliCE extends the robust-recourse agenda of ROAR by shifting robustness from local input perturbations to robustness over a family of near-optimal models, with provable guarantees.

prior_works.title: Robust solutions of uncertain linear programs
prior_works.role: Ellipsoidal uncertainty sets and tractable robust optimization
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ElliCE leverages the robust optimization machinery pioneered here—particularly the use of ellipsoidal uncertainty sets that yield convex, tractable programs—to enforce validity of recourse across the Rashomon ellipsoid.

prior_works.title: Robustness and Regularization Are Equivalent
prior_works.authors: Huan Xu, Constantine Caramanis, Shie Mannor
prior_works.role: Link between parameter robustness and quadratic regularization
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ElliCE’s ellipsoidal (quadratic) approximation of the Rashomon set and its proofs of uniqueness and stability draw on the equivalence between ellipsoidal robustness and L2-type regularization, supporting its theoretical guarantees.

synthesis_narrative:
ElliCE’s core contribution—provably robust algorithmic recourse across the Rashomon set—sits at the confluence of counterfactual recourse, model multiplicity, and robust optimization. Foundational works on counterfactual explanations and actionable recourse (Wachter et al.; Ustun et al.) established counterfactuals as optimization problems with costs and feasibility constraints, but they target a single fitted model. Subsequent evidence of predictive multiplicity (Marx, Calmon, Ustun) exposed a key vulnerability: actions valid for one near-optimal model can fail under another, motivating robustness to an entire set of plausible models rather than to local perturbations alone.
The Rashomon set literature (Fisher, Rudin, Dominici) formalized this set-of-good-models perspective and studied feature importance across it. ElliCE translates this conceptual lens into an operational tool by proposing an ellipsoidal approximation of the Rashomon set around an empirical risk minimizer, enabling optimization of counterfactuals that are guaranteed valid throughout the set. This move is technically grounded in robust optimization with ellipsoidal uncertainty (Ben-Tal, Nemirovski), which provides convex, tractable robust counterparts and natural certificates. Moreover, the equivalence between robustness to parameter perturbations and quadratic regularization (Xu, Caramanis, Mannor) underpins ElliCE’s guarantees on uniqueness and stability via strong convexity of the ellipsoidal level sets.
Relative to prior robust recourse (e.g., ROAR), which focuses on robustness to input noise or local perturbations, ElliCE explicitly targets model uncertainty induced by multiplicity, offering theoretical guarantees on validity, uniqueness, and alignment with salient feature directions across the Rashomon set.
